choices.A: Snowflake will charge for 36 seconds at the rate of 32 credits per hour.
choices.D: Snowflake will charge for 60 seconds at the rate of 64 credits per hour.
choices.C: Snowflake will charge for 60 seconds at the rate of 32 credits per hour.
choices.B: Snowflake will charge for 36 seconds at the rate of 64 credits per hour.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The rate of 64 credits per hour is based on the size of the virtual warehouse. In Snowflake, the credit consumption rate for a virtual warehouse is determined by its size. A 2XL virtual warehouse consumes 64 credits per hour

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-overview#warehouse-size

2X -> 32 credit /hour considering min 60 seconds a VM runs

questions.question_text:
A Snowflake user runs a query for 36 seconds on a size 2XL virtual warehouse.

What would be the credit consumption?
What value provides information about disk usage for operations where intermediate results do not fit in memory in a Query Profile?
What is an advantage of using a multi-cluster virtual warehouse as compared to a single-cluster virtual warehouse in Snowflake?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D.
In Auto-scale mode multi-cluster warehouse eliminates the need for resizing the warehouse or starting and stopping additional warehouses to handle fluctuating workloads.

choices.C: A user can resize a warehouse at any time whether running or not.
choices.B: A user can specify a warehouse size while configuring it for use.
choices.D: A user can specify the maximum and minimum number of cluster(s).
choices.A: A user can auto-suspend a running warehouse due to inactivity.

choices.B: The column name and element names are both case-insensitive.
choices.C: The column name is case-sensitive but element names are case-insensitive.
choices.D: The column name is case-insensitive but element names are case-sensitive.
choices.A: The column name and element names are both case-sensitive.

questions.question_text: Regardless of which notation is used, what are considerations for writing the column name and element names when traversing semi-structured data?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Regardless of which notation you use, the column name is case-insensitive but element names are case-sensitive. For example, (src is a column name) in the following list, the first two paths are equivalent, but the third is not:
src:salesperson.name
SRC:salesperson.name
SRC:Salesperson.Name

questions.question_text: Which Snowflake data type is used to store JSON key value pairs?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/data-types-semistructured
VARIANT and OBJECT can contain key-value pairs
